Garden

Welcome to the garden üåºüå∏üå∫

This generative artwork is a symbolic journey through the natural cycle of life and death, conveyed through a dynamic weather-to-nature transition and mathematical floral growth.

It begins with a storm, a metaphor for chaos, fear, and the inevitable forces of time. Heavy clouds roam, rain lashes down, and flashes of lightning tear the sky‚Äîsuggesting the unpredictable onset of life or the turbulence near death. The environment is dark, uncertain, and moving.

Then, a transition unfolds. Light slowly returns as the storm fades. The sun rises, illuminating a world now teeming with growth. Grass, ferns, and flowers bloom using parametric equations‚Äîlife structured through nature‚Äôs mathematical order. Butterflies emerge, fluttering in soft figure-eights, symbolizing rebirth, fragility, and fleeting joy.

The dandelion appears last‚Äîa poignant symbol of both life and impermanence. Initially grounded, it transitions into its ‚Äúblown‚Äù state. It‚Äôs the final breath, the quiet release, but also a beginning for new life elsewhere.

Each flower, each motion, each particle serves as a visual metaphor:

  • The storm for hardship and the unknown.
  • The sunlight and bloom for life, hope, and becoming.
  • The dandelion seeds for decay, remembrance, and return.

In this piece, death is not an end‚Äîit is a transition, as natural and necessary as a storm giving way to sun. Life, in turn, is brief, beautiful, and blooming‚Äîalways on the verge of letting go.

Butterfly‚Äôs movement follows a figure-eight trajectory, which can be modeled using sine and cosine functions: 

x(t) = A¬∑cos(œâ‚Çì¬∑t)
y(t) = B¬∑sin(œâ·µß¬∑t)

These functions create smooth, looping motion‚Äîjust like how real butterflies flutter rather than flying straight. Each butterfly has a slightly different frequency (œâ), making its motion unique.

To keep them from flying off too far, we constrain their range: 

x ‚àà [x‚ÇÄ ‚àí d‚Çì, x‚ÇÄ + d‚Çì]
y ‚àà [y‚ÇÄ ‚àí d·µß, y‚ÇÄ + d·µß]

This ensures they stay within a specific area, rather than wandering infinitely.

Dandelions and seed dispersal use polar coordinates to arrange seeds in a circular pattern: 

x = r¬∑cos(Œ∏)
y = r¬∑sin(Œ∏)

Here, r is the radius and Œ∏ the angle‚Äîthis evenly spaces seeds around the center.

To animate the dandelion blooming, we apply a scaling transformation: 

S(t) = [
  sx(t)   0
   0    sy(t)
]

Where sx and sy scale the flower‚Äôs size based on bloom progress.

The seeds don‚Äôt remain static‚Äîthey sway gently with the wind: 

x_seed = x‚ÇÄ + A¬∑sin(œâ¬∑t)

This adds life and movement, as if the seeds are truly floating away.
